sub_topic: Determining the bond enthalpy of a molecule
message_1: What is the bond enthalpy of O-H bond in the molecule H2O? Show the calculation involved in determining the enthalpy change required to break one mole of O-H bonds in water.
message_2:
The bond enthalpy of the O-H bond in water (H2O) is the amount of energy required to break one mole of O-H bonds in the molecule. The bond enthalpy of the O-H bond in water is approximately 463 kJ/mol.

To calculate the enthalpy change required to break one mole of O-H bonds in water, we need to consider that there are two O-H bonds in one molecule of water. Therefore, the enthalpy change for breaking one mole of O-H bonds in water can be calculated as follows:

Enthalpy change = Bond enthalpy of O-H bond × Number of O-H bonds in one molecule of water
Enthalpy change = 463 kJ/mol × 2
Enthalpy change = 926 kJ/mol

So, the enthalpy change required to break one mole of O-H bonds in water is 926 kJ/mol.
